subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
msgSnippet: Elliotte, Just as a few months ago, I m going to agree to disagree on this point. As an extender (most often of Eclipse), I find myself often wanting extension
messageBody:
Elliotte,

Just as a few months ago, I'm going to agree to disagree on this point.
As an extender (most often of Eclipse), I find myself often wanting
extension hooks for things that were hard-coded. Now, if I were to ask
the Eclipse framework writers to think about, document, publish, and
guarantee to all the world for all time an API for what I'm requesting,
it would be too much to ask. A middle ground seems the fair solution:
they open the door, with documentation that it's in an internal package,
or only for people who know what they're doing, and I promise to know
what I'm doing.

As an extender, I don't want there to be only published and committed
for all the world, and private to everyone. To use an online publishing
metaphor, I'm willing to pay the cost for a premium subscription, in
reading undocumented source code and risk of future breakage. :) And
when that premium subscription is offered without my asking, then I can
get my extension to market quicker, which makes me happier about
Eclipse, and Eclipse a more useful and used platform.

That's just my experience. Some clarification on terminology, and then
I'm done:

Elliotte Harold wrote:

> David Saff wrote:
>
> > My experience is that it is best to allow a gradient to your users and
> > extenders. There should be public, javadoc'ed, committed, released
> API,
> > but there should also be some beta API's, protected methods without
> > commitment, public implementation classes in packages marked internal.
> > Is it necessary that the presence of the latter should interfere at all
> > with the comprehensibility or quality of the former?
>
> Beta APIs should not be part of an official release. They should be part
> of clearly marked beta releases where users know hat they're getting
> into before they use them.

Of course.

> Protected methods are part of the published API and there's no reason to
> expect users not to rely on them. marking something "protected" only
> reflects its access protection. It doesn't mean it's more or less likely
> to change in the future. Overloading the word "protected" in this way
> can only serve to confuse users.

Sorry. I meant "without commitment" meaning "documented as possibly
unstable", not that all protected methods were automatically to be
understood as implicitly so documented.

> Packages documented internal are a code smell, and should be avoided.
> Usually these can be made genuinely non-public in an existing package
> instead.

I agree to disagree.

David Saff
